body: No - that’s ok. I’ve set the minimum Rust version to 1.28 for a while now, so I think we should be fine.
Would it be better for the language runtime to return a `204` indicating a successful request but no content?
Build failure caused by a PEBCAK on my part (forgot to change enum variant names in cross-tests). Fixing now.

Sounds like an improvement, but here's the issue I think exists with oneway:

1. Generated client code sends a oneway request.
2. HTTP transport packages it up and send it to the server.  This could be through a proxy.
3. Server receives it.  Since it is a oneway request, my assumption is the server, no matter what the language, has a HTTP transport that issues a response (like 200 OK without content, or 204 as you stated).  If it did not, it wouldn't work through a proxy (or at least, the proxy might behave badly).
An example of this can be found at https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/lib/py/src/server/THttpServer.py#L86.
4. Client has no generated response reader code because it is oneway, so the client code never attempts to get the transport response (which is fair, oneway probably came around before we had a transport with a mandatory response).  However now there's a transport reply sitting in the buffer.
5. The next request sent by the client that is normal (not oneway) would send the request and then read the HTTP 1.1 200 OK response buffered from from the oneway request, and the actual reply to the two-way request would get queued up; however the response processor for the twoway request, seeing no payload, would throw an exception.
I assume the default setting is to use the previous way, and this is a new way, so it is backwards compatible?
Oh. Hmm - you're absolutely right. Because the autogen'd code is protocol agnostic it doesn't know that in some cases the protocol has no concept of a one-way interaction.
I did not include a flag for backwards-compatibility. I'd prefer not to, because this change makes the autogenerated code conform to Rust naming conventions.
Yes - you're right: it is a breaking change. I'll make the README entries, and make sure I do so for any (hopefully rare!) breaking changes I make in the future. Thank you for catching this.
I've updated the `CHANGES` file, plus added a `Compatibility` section to the Rust `README` along with transition guidelines. I will do this in the future for any breaking changes.
@jeking3 I've made the requested changes, and, the only thing that fails in Travis is the SBCL build under autotools :/ Could this be merged please?
@jeking3 These changes look good. Could they be merged please? All the cross-tests pass. Two build failures: SBCL (same issue as before) and D.
@jeikabu TY for the PR! I guess this tells you I didn't check that I could implement new transports from outside the crate :/ I'll make sure of that in the future.
@jeking3 Could this be merged please? The only build failure is with D, with the SSL server unable to bind in one build.

@jeking3 I updated PR. You were right about oneway - server returns 200 OK with empty body. Looks like https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1602/files#diff-74eb8d4b20c423c78252e3e3dc847099R227 unintentionally fixed a bug, and the original version of this PR would have broken it.

I tested with simple service that has both oneway and regular functions, everything was fully functional. I noticed php client will block until it gets response, but that's a different problem.
Any updates on the 0.12.0 release? We'd like to move away from referencing a specific commit to using an official version. Anything I can help with?

Sorry to rip open an old issue, but this actually break things for me, since my typedefs are actually generated with the "Typedef_" id! 
(Don't know if anything have changed since this was resolved)

Example:
In a project of mine, we are sometimes using typedefs to simplify imports, so say we have example.thrift containing:
```
import "../path/to/filename_may_change.thrift"

typedef filename_may_change.SomeStruct SomeStruct

struct SomeOtherStruct {
    1: SomeStruct some_struct;
}
```
This allows me to simply use SomeStruct instead of filename_may_change.SomeStruct in the definitions, and when the filename changes (for instance if version is included in the filenames), I only have to update in the import and typedef, instead of multiple places in the thrift file.

However, currently this causes some issues in the generated html, since the actual ids for the typedefs in the html is "example.html#Typedef_SomeStruct" (which is also used in the links in the generated TOC rows). 
However further down in the usages of SomeStruct, for instance under SomeOtherStruct, the generated html under Type tries to link to "example.html#Struct_SomeStruct", which obviously doesn't exist.

It would be fine for me if it was aligned, so the TOC links and the actual ID's are the same as in the links in Data Structures, but currently at least this is not working for me. 
I can't actually imagine that the TOC links are working properly in your use case, since they are generated with #Typedef_ as well?

(Alternatively, they could link directly to the "filename_may_change.html#[...]", but that is probably more tricky.)

Hi @jeking3 I added nodets to cross test suite

...or not. I think I missed something, the test didn't run. I will check why.

You can run the cross test locally if you use the docker build container.  First you prepare the environment:
```
user@ubuntu:~/thrift$ docker pull thrift/thrift-build:ubuntu-bionic
user@ubuntu:~/thrift$ docker run -v $(pwd):/thrift/src:rw -it thrift/thrift-build:ubuntu-bionic /bin/bash
root@8d4584e2e789:/thrift/src# ./bootstrap.sh
root@8d4584e2e789:/thrift/src# ./configure
root@8d4584e2e789:/thrift/src# make precross
```
Next you can run a specific combination of tests:

```
root@8d4584e2e789:/thrift/src# test/test.py --retry-count 5 --skip-known-failures --server cpp --client nodets
```

That will help you prepare your next pull request for success.

The `nodets` uses `nodejs` as a basis so known failures for `nodejs` probably applies to `nodets` as well.
I will check if there are any that `nodejs` doesn't fail.

I did some improvements to the tests script so most timeouts are fixed.

the `erl-nodets` and `d-nodets` tests fail but their `nodejs` counterparts are in `known_failures_Linux.json` so they should be added as well.

There is one test that I couldn't figure out: In `hs-nodets` test, the client logs that all the tests are successful and it does call `connection.end()`. However it still times out for some reason...
Do the best you can, and then add the rest to the known failures list.  The builds need to pass.  If something environmental or unrelated to your changes comes up, I can restart a job.

Hi @jeking3 I have a green build but I had to disable `hs-nodets` test. 

If it is OK with you, can we merge this PR and then I can take a deeper look into the test with my colleagues?

https://thrift.apache.org/docs/Languages

Thanks for merging it.

Here is the necessary info (the cross test covers the following cases):
- nodets
- since: 0.12.0 (next release, I guess)
- lang/lib levels: Min: TypeScript 3.1.6
- Low level transports: Socket
- Transport wrappers: TLS
- Protocols: binary
- Servers: Simple
Amazing. Now the CL build is failing with another error, specifically that it doesn't have permissions to write an out file...
Second try: it appears that executing the builds sequentially doesn't help because the same path is being used for the compiler cache? I think? So I'll try disabling it.
Going to force push a couple of times to kick off the builds and see if the SBCL error pops up. If it doesn't I can tentatively claim victory. The first run was successful, so...let's hope.

This is looking good. I've force-pushed a few times to re-kick the Travis builds and I'm no longer seeing CL-related failures (whereas before at least one or two would pop up). I'm hoping to receive a review from the original CL contributor, but if not I'll submit by EOW. Looking forward to a stable Thrift build!
Shall I merge?

I'm closing this as it's really old and there hasn't been much feedback.

Feel free to use the code if you see fit!
Why not use Github instead of Gitbox? We already do that for the Go library.

https://github.com/apache/thrift is just a mirror of Gitbox.
Technically, the work flow doesn't relay on GitHub. That's why we used git-wip-us, and why we use gitbox.

I think it's the other way around, pushes to Github are mirrored to Gitbox. I've personally never pushed to Gitbox.

I also distinctly remember (because it became a problem for Go) us calling Github the official primary repo after git-wip-us was shutdown.
Per THRIFT-4441, we're dropping C++03 support going forward, so you can replace these with `noexcept` if you prefer.

Author indicated insufficient time to complete the PR, and the changes don't appear to actually change anything other than a variable name.  In addition the tests did not pass.  This will be closed in favor of THRIFT-4405 verifying correctness.

We've pretty much cleared the way to a C++11 only thrift release post-0.12.0... whether you want to be involved or not is up to you @typz but we'd be happier if you were. :)

@Heromyth I'd love to see this move to completion.  Any chance you will be able to address the remaining issues?  We've made a lot of progress with dlang in 0.12.0, we're even in dub now.  It's possible some of this work is no longer needed.  Not sure.
I'm not great with Erlang either. Since there are outstanding questions about this PR, I'd rather just close.

The fact is that Erlang implementation is lacking this basic functionality that other language implementations have.
Whether we close this PR or not can we agree that we have a problem and that there should be a separate issue open that details the missing functionality?
Sure, if there's an alternate implementation that we can plug in and enable cross tests on with more transports and protocols supported that would be great.

Hello @jeking3  Thanks for the look over!

So, interestingly, the LANGUAGES.md file already states that Thrift supports "1.8.0_151".

I reviewed the Docker build files and they do reflect the update to Java 1.8.

In regards to Ant, I would like to request that we table that for a different JIRA in order to more thoroughly examine if it is still a dependent.  I see it's still being installed as a dependency in the Docker container, so it may still be needed.  Either way, this should be done in a new JIRA.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-4701
@jeking3 All of the checks passed and I opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-4701 to look into the Ant dependency.  Please consider including this pull request.
This change is not backward compatible as the scope of the AutoExpandingBuffer class has been minimized from public to package-level.

There is a conflict, a file was removed - please rebase on master.

When you rebase you want to do this:

* git checkout master
* git pull
* git checkout [your branch]
* git rebase master
* git push -u [your personal fork name] [your branch] --force
Thanks @jeking3 ! Ya, I'm still getting my head around git, GitHub is helpful to verify.  I knew it was wrong. :)
How certain are we that these code paths are properly unit tested?
